After taking your position firmly, wisely, cautiously, make not one concession on any point concerning which God has plainly spoken. Be as calm as a summer evening, but as fixed as the everlasting hills. By conceding you would be selling our whole cause into the hands of the enemy. The cause of God is not to be traded away. We must now take hold of these matters decidedly.--Letter 216, 1903, p. 6. (To the Leaders in Our Medical Work, August 4, 1903.) 

White Estate Washington, D. C. August 20, 1981
